Tables

The primary method of displaying data of any sort is through the use of tables.

Each row contains supporting data relative to a specific piece of information at either a high level or detailed level.

Tables are also used to break multiple actions requiring input on a screen into easily manageable pieces.

Overview

In data heavy experiences tables are used to display and organize information proactively, making information requiring immediate action rise to the forefront.

Tables in CEMEX applications are used to display:

1) High level summaries

2) Detailed information on a particular element

3) Actionable tasks

Informational Tables

Informational tables are used to list all pieces of information for the section being viewed. Each row contains carefully selected data to provide the user enough context to make a decision if necessary while giving them the ability to select the row and view supporting pieces of information for a holistic view.

Rules:

1) Maximum # of Columns - 7, Minimum # of Columns - 3

2) Monetary Amounts and numbers should always be right aligned

3) No text or numbers should ever be centered

4) The placement of status should always be in the the first column on all tables across all products so that the user gets familiar with where to find it.

5) Limit address to a max of 40 characters. If the address is longer, fade out the ending of the address.

Detailed Tables

Detail tables provide a detailed view of any given row of an Informational Table.
Detailed Tables are comprised of:

1) A header, displaying the same information from the selected Informational Table row andâ€¦

2) Data rows below the header, displaying detailed items that go into creating the summary of the header

Occasionally, Actionable Table rows will occurr after the supporting data rows.
These are detailed on the following pages of this section.
